title: How to Preserve a Tree Stump

steps.title: Wipe the top and bottom of the stump with a wet cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the top and bottom of the stump with a wet cloth. Start by cleaning off any dirt or surface debris on the stump with a cloth. Rub the wood grain in a gentle, circular motion on the top and bottom, where the stump has been cut. [1] X Research source Do not wipe the bark with the cloth, as this can cause the bark to flake or fall off.

steps.title: Remove any flaking wood or bark on the stump.
steps.content: Remove any flaking wood or bark on the stump. Use your hands to gently pull off any wood that is flaking off of the stump, especially on areas with bark. Make sure you take off any twigs, bugs, or leaves on the stump.

steps.title: Take off the bark if it appears dead or dry.
steps.content: Take off the bark if it appears dead or dry. Removing the bark is up to you, as you can keep it on if there is not a black ring between the bark and the wood, and if the bark does not appear too dry. Use a rotary hammer to remove the bark, sliding it from the top to the bottom of the stump. The bark should peel off easily, leaving you with just wood around the stump. [2] X Research source Leaving the bark on will give the stump a more rustic look. If you remove it, you will need to sand down the sides of the stump.

steps.title: Smooth the perimeter of the stump with a planer.
steps.content: Smooth the perimeter of the stump with a planer. A planer is a power tool with a flat head that helps to even out a surface. Run the planer around the top and bottom perimeters of the stump to remove any rough spots. Do this until the top and bottom edges of the stump are smooth to the touch. [3] X Research source Use a broom or cloth to wipe off any debris after you have finished smoothing the edges.

steps.title: Use 80-grit sandpaper on the top and bottom of the stump.
steps.content: Use 80-grit sandpaper on the top and bottom of the stump. Rub the sandpaper on the top of the stump in a circular motion, removing the top layer of wood. The sandpaper is also a great way to even out the top of the stump so the surface is level. Then, rub the sandpaper on the bottom of the stump, removing the top layer. [4] X Research source If you removed the bark around the stump, you will need to sand the sides of the stump as well. Sand the stump from top to bottom with the sandpaper to smooth the sides. Wear gloves when you use the sandpaper to protect your hands.

steps.title: Use an electric sander if the stump is very dirty or rough.
steps.content: Use an electric sander if the stump is very dirty or rough. The electric sander is a great way to smooth out the top and bottom of the stump quickly. Run it back and forth over the top and bottom of the stump, revealing the fresh wood underneath. [5] X Research source As you sand the stump, you should notice the rings in the wood being exposed on the top and bottom. This means you are exposing fresh wood.

steps.title: Wipe the stump with a damp, lint free cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the stump with a damp, lint free cloth. Once you have finished sanding the stump, remove wood dust with a cloth. Give the top and bottom of the stump a good wipe so the wood appears clean and fresh. [6] X Research source If you sanded the sides of the stump, you should wipe this area down as well.

steps.title: Fill in cracks in the wood with wood filler.
steps.content: Fill in cracks in the wood with wood filler. If the stump has any large or deep cracks that you do not want to keep, you can fill them with a wood filler like clear epoxy. Put tape on the sides and bottom of the stump, below the cracks, to prevent the epoxy from leaking out of the cracks. Then, drizzle the epoxy into the cracks to fill them. [7] X Research source Apply 1 layer of epoxy to fill the cracks and let it dry overnight. Wear gloves when you handle the epoxy, as it is a strong chemical.

steps.title: Get wood stabilizer at your local hardware store or online.
steps.content: Get wood stabilizer at your local hardware store or online. Wood stabilizer comes as a liquid that you rub into wood. It contains ingredients that will prevent the wood from warping, cracking, or checking. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Rub 1⁄2 cup (120 ml) of stabilizer into the top of the stump.
steps.content: Rub 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 ml) of stabilizer into the top of the stump. Start with a small amount of stabilizer and then add more as needed. Use a clean dry cloth to rub the stabilizer into the wood in a circular motion. Cover the entire top of the stump with the stabilizer, rubbing it into the wood grain. [9] X Research source The wood will absorb the stabilizer as you rub it in so you may need to pour on more to ensure the entire surface is covered.

steps.title: Cover the top of the stump in plastic and let it dry for 2-4 hours.
steps.content: Cover the top of the stump in plastic and let it dry for 2-4 hours. Tie a plastic sheet or tarp over the top of the stump to allow the stabilizer to dry properly. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Apply 1⁄2 cup (120 ml) of stabilizer on the bottom of the stump with a cloth.
steps.content: Apply 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 ml) of stabilizer on the bottom of the stump with a cloth. Once the top of the stump has dried, flip the stump over and repeat the same steps on the bottom of the stump. Cover the bottom of the stump with the stabilizer, getting it right in the wood grain. [11] X Research source Once you have applied the stabilizer, cover the bottom of the stump with plastic and let it dry for 2-4 hours.

steps.title: Put at least 2 coats of stabilizer on the stump.
steps.content: Put at least 2 coats of stabilizer on the stump. To really seal the stump, apply at least 2 coats of stabilizer, letting the top and bottom of the stump dry for 2-4 hours between coats. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Apply sealer spray to the bark.
steps.content: Apply sealer spray to the bark. To prevent bark and wood pieces from falling off the sides of the stump, seal the bark with a clear gloss finishing spray. Apply the spray around the sides of the stump from top to bottom. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the sealer to dry overnight.
steps.content: Allow the sealer to dry overnight. Place the stump in a dry spot outside, such as in your garage or a work shed, and let it dry overnight. This will give the sealer time to set so the stump is ready for use. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Attach metal legs to the bottom of the stump, if desired.
steps.content: Attach metal legs to the bottom of the stump, if desired. If you want to elevate the stump and use it as a side table, you may attach legs to the bottom using screws and a power drill. Get 3 thin metal legs, such as hairpin legs, and drill them into the bottom of the stump for a more polished look. [15] X Research source Alternatively, you can skip the legs and use the stump as a rustic side table.
